密码学：公钥加密

发表于 2020-10-20 阅读次数：
本文字数： 20k 阅读时长 ≈ 18 分钟

Math related with public-key encryption

Diffie-Hellman problems

Fix a cyclic group G\mathbb{G}G and a generator g∈Gg\in \mathbb{G}g∈G. Given elements h1,h2∈Gh_{1},h_{2}\in \mathbb{G}h1​,h2​∈G, define DHg(h1,h2)=gloggh1⋅loggh2DH_{g}(h_{1},h_{2})=g^{log_{g}h_{1}\cdot log_{g}h_{2}}DHg​(h1​,h2​)=glogg​h1​⋅logg​h2​. That is, if h1=gx1h_{1}=g^{x_{1}}h1​=gx1​ and h2=gx2h_{2}=g^{x_{2}}h2​=gx2​ then

DHg(h1,h2)=gx1⋅x2=h1x2=h2x1DH_{g}(h_{1},h_{2})=g^{x_{1}\cdot x_{2}}=h_{1}^{x_{2}}=h_{2}^{x_{1}} DHg​(h1​,h2​)=gx1​⋅x2​=h1x2​​=h2x1​​

The computational Diffie-Hellman(CDH) problem is to compute DHg(h1,h2)DH_{g}(h_{1},h_{2})DHg​(h1​,h2​) for uniform h1h_1h1​ and h2h_2h2​. It is not clear whether hardness of the discrete-logarithm problem implies that the CDH problem is hard as well.

The decisional Diffie-Hellman(DDH) problem is, when given uniform h1,h2h_{1},h_{2}h1​,h2​ and a third group element h′h'h′, distinguish whether h′=DHg(h1,h2)h'=DH_{g}(h_{1},h_{2})h′=DHg​(h1​,h2​) or h′h'h′ is chosen from a uniform group element.

RSA generation

Key management evolution

key distribution in private-key encryption

Problems

  • Key distribution: The key must be shared through a secure channel.
  • Storing and managing large number of secret keys: N people communicating with each other need to store N-1 secret keys for each one.
  • Inapplicability of private-key cryptography to open systems: can not interact with new users.

Key-distribution centers

A key-distribution center(KDC) can become a partial solution for the problem above. An entity trusted by all the users serves as a key-distribution center and it helps all the users share pairwise keys.

Offline fashion: When a new people iii join, the KDC shares a key with this people, and also distributes n−1n-1n−1 shared keys between iii and other 1∼i−11\sim i-11∼i−1 people.

Online fashion: Generate key on demand whenever Alice and Bob need to communicate securely. Choose a new, random key kkk, then send to Alice encrypted using kAk_{A}kA​ and to Bob encrypted using kBk_{B}kB​. (kAk_{A}kA​ is a private key between KDC and Alice)

The KDC can alleviate two of the problem: the key distribution is simplified, and the key storage is eased.

There are also some drawbacks: the KDC is a single point of failure, and a successful attack on the KDC will result in a complete break of the system.

Needham-Schroder protocol

A protocol for secure key distribution using KDC. One of its features is that KDC sends to Alice the session key encrypted under Alice’s key in addition to the session key encrypted under Bob’s key. Alice then sends the second ciphertext to Bob as a credential that allows Alice talk to Bob.

The process is shown as the following figure:

Diffie-Hellman protocol

The KDC approaches still require a private and authenticated channel that can be used to share keys, so it is still not applicable in open systems.

Diffie and Hellman’s paper stated that there are certain actions that can be easily performed but not easily reversed. This phenomena could be used to derive interactive protocols for sercure key exchange that allow two parties to share a secret key via communication over a public but authenticated channel, by having the parties perform operations that they can reverse but that an eavesdropper cannot.

Secure key exchange

The key-exchange experiment KEA,πeav(n)KE_{\mathcal{A},\pi}^{eav}(n)KEA,πeav​(n):

  1. Two parties holding 1n1^n1n execute protocol Π\PiΠ. This results in a transcript transtranstrans containing all the messages sent by the parties, and a key kkk output by each of the parties.

  2. A uniform bit b∈{0,1}b\in \{0,1\}b∈{0,1} is chosen. If b=0b=0b=0 set k^:=k\hat{k}:=kk^:=k, and if b=1 then choose k^∈{0,1}n\hat{k}\in \{0,1\}^{n}k^∈{0,1}n uniformly at random

  3. A\mathcal{A}A is given transtranstrans and k^\hat{k}k^, and output a bit b′b'b′

  4. The output of the experiment is defined to be 1 if b′=bb'=bb′=b and 0 otherwise. In the case that KEA,πeav(n)=1KE_{\mathcal{A},\pi}^{eav}(n)=1KEA,πeav​(n)=1 we say that A\mathcal{A}A succeeds.

A key-exchange protocol Π\PiΠ is secure in the presence of \textit{an eavesdropper} if for all probabilistic polynomial-time adversaries A\mathcal{A}A there is a negligible function neglneglnegl such that

Pr[KEA,πeav(n)=1]≤12+negl(n)Pr[KE_{\mathcal{A},\pi}^{eav}(n)=1]\le \frac{1}{2}+negl(n) Pr[KEA,πeav​(n)=1]≤21​+negl(n)

The Diffie-Hellman key-exchange protocol

Let G\mathcal{G}G be a probabilistic polynomial-time algorithm that, on input 1n1^n1n, outputs a description of a cyclic group G\mathbb{G}G, its order qqq with ∣∣q∣∣=n||q||=n∣∣q∣∣=n, and a generator g∈Gg\in \mathbb{G}g∈G. The Diffie-Hellman key-exchange protocol can be described as follows:

  • Common input: The security parameter 1n1^n1n.
  • The protocol:
    1. Alice runs G(1n)\mathcal{G}(1^{n})G(1n) to obtain (G,q,g)(\mathbb{G},q,g)(G,q,g).
    2. Alice chooses a uniform x∈Zqx\in \mathbb{Z}_{q}x∈Zq​, and computes hA:=gxh_{A}:=g^xhA​:=gx.
    3. Alice sends (G,q,g,hA)(\mathbb{G},q,g,h_{A})(G,q,g,hA​) to Bob.
    4. Bob receives (G,q,g,hA)(\mathbb{G},q,g,h_{A})(G,q,g,hA​). He chooses a uniform y∈Zqy\in \mathbb{Z}_{q}y∈Zq​, and computes hB:=gyh_{B}:=g^yhB​:=gy. Bob sends hBh_{B}hB​ to Alice and outputs the key kB:=hAyk_{B}:=h_{A}^{y}kB​:=hAy​.
    5. Alice receives hBh_{B}hB​ and outputs the key kA:=hBxk_{A}:=h_{B}^{x}kA​:=hBx​.

The following figure illustrate the construction of Diffie-Hellman key-exchange protocol:

If the decisional Diffie-Hellman problem is hard relative to G\mathcal{G}G, then the Diffie-Hellman key-exchange protocol Π\PiΠ is secure in the presence of an eavesdropper.

Please note that the shared key is indistinguishable from a uniform element of G\mathbb{G}G rather than from a uniform n-bit string.

In order to use the key for subsequent cryptographic applications, the key output by the parties should be indistinguishable from a uniform bit-string of the appropriate length. The Diffie-Hellman protocol can be modified to achieve this by using an appropriate key-derivation function.

Diffie-Hellman protocol is completely insecure against man-in-the-middle attacks (both honest parties are executing the protocol and the adversary is intercepting and modifying messages being sent from one party to the other). But it is the core of standardized key-exchange protocols today.

Public-key encryption

Overview

In public-key encryption, the receiver generates a pair of keys (pk,sk)(pk,sk)(pk,sk), called the public key and private key respectively. The public key is used by the sender to encrypt a message; the receiver uses the private key to decrypt the resulting ciphertext.

Two ways to learn pkpkpk (Alice is the receiver and Bob is the sender):

  1. When Alice learns that Bob wants to communicate with her, generate (pk,sk)(pk,sk)(pk,sk) and then send pkpkpk to Bob in the clear.

  2. Alice generate her keys (pk,sk)(pk,sk)(pk,sk) in advance, independently of any particular sender. Then she can widely disseminate pkpkpk so that anyone who wishes to communicate with her can use pkpkpk directly.

Some important notes for public-key encryption:

  • The security of public-key encryption relies on the secrecy of sksksk.
  • The security of public-key encryption is under the assumption that the sender are able to obtain a legitimate copy of the receiver’s public key.

Comparison with private-key encryption:

  • Advantages:

    1. The key-distribution could be done over public but authenticated channels, since pkpkpk do not need to be secret.
    2. Reduce the need for users to store many secret keys.
    3. More suitable for open environments.

  • Drawbacks:

    1. The receiver could receive messages from anyone. (When receiver only wants to receive the message from specific invididuals it is a drawback).
    2. Roughly 2 to 3 orders of magnitude slower than private-key encryption.

Public-key encryption scheme

A public-key encryption scheme is a triple of probabilistic polynomial-time algorithms (Gen,Enc,Dec)(Gen,Enc,Dec)(Gen,Enc,Dec) such that:

  1. The key-generation algorithm GenGenGen takes the security parameter 1n1^n1n as input and outputs a pair of keys (pk,sk)(pk,sk)(pk,sk). We refer to the first of these as the \textit{public key} and the second as \textit{private key}. Assuming for convenience that pkpkpk and sksksk each has length at least nnn, and nnn can be determined from pk,skpk,skpk,sk.
  2. The encryption algorithm EncEncEnc takes a public key pkpkpk and a message mmm from some message space (depend on pkpkpk) as input. It outputs a ciphertext ccc, and we write it as c←Encpk(m)c\leftarrow Enc_{pk}(m)c←Encpk​(m). (Write this way means that EncEncEnc is probabilistic, which is needed to achieve meaningful security)
  3. The deterministic decryption algorithm DecDecDec takes a private key sksksk and a ciphertext ccc as input, and outputs a message mmm or a special symbol denoting failure. We write this as m:=Decsk(c)m:=Dec_{sk}(c)m:=Decsk​(c).

KEM/DEM paradigm

Hybrid encryption

In hybrid encryption, both private-key encryption and public-key encryption are used. The aims of using hybrid encryption:

  • Private-key encryption can increase efficiency.
  • Using public-key encryption to increase bandwidth.

Note that although the private-key encryption is used as a component, this method still belongs to public encryption schemes, since the sender and receiver do not share any secret key in advance.

Construction

A key-encapsulation mechanism(KEM) is a tuple of probabilistic polynomial-time algorithms (Gen,Encaps,Decaps)(Gen,Encaps,Decaps)(Gen,Encaps,Decaps) such that:

  1. The key-generation algorithm GenGenGen takes as input the security parameter 1n1^n1n and outputs a public-/private-key pair (pk,sk)(pk,sk)(pk,sk). Assuming that pkpkpk and sksksk each has length at least nnn, and nnn can be determined from pk,skpk,skpk,sk.

  2. The encapsulation algorithm EncapsEncapsEncaps takes as input a public key pkpkpk and the security parameter 1n1^n1n. It outputs a ciphertext ccc and a key k∈{0,1}ℓ(n)k\in \{0,1\}^{\ell (n)}k∈{0,1}ℓ(n) where ℓ\ellℓ is the key length. It can be written as (c,k)←Encapspk(1n)(c,k)\leftarrow Encaps_{pk}(1^{n})(c,k)←Encapspk​(1n).

  3. The deterministic decapsulation algorithm DecapsDecapsDecaps takes as input a private key sksksk and a ciphertext ccc, and outputs a key kkk or a special symbol denoting failure. We write this as k:=Decapssk(c)k:=Decaps_{sk}(c)k:=Decapssk​(c).

By using a KEM, a key kkk is generated and then is used for private-key encryption.
The private-key encrypton scheme is called the data-encapsulation mechanism(DEM).

Using the construction above, we can construct hybrid encryption using the KEM/DEM paradigm:

Let Π=(Gen,Encaps,Decaps)\Pi=(Gen,Encaps,Decaps)Π=(Gen,Encaps,Decaps) be a KEM with key length nnn, and let Π′=(Gen′,Enc′,Dec′)\Pi'=(Gen',Enc',Dec')Π′=(Gen′,Enc′,Dec′) be a private-key encryption scheme. Construct a public-key encryption scheme Πhy=(Genhy,Enchy,Dechy)\Pi^{hy}=(Gen^{hy},Enc^{hy},Dec^{hy})Πhy=(Genhy,Enchy,Dechy) as follows:

  • GenhyGen^{hy}Genhy: on input 1n1^n1n run Gen(1n)Gen(1^{n})Gen(1n) and use the public and private keys (pk,sk)(pk,sk)(pk,sk) that are output.

  • EnchyEnc^{hy}Enchy: on input a public key pkpkpk and a message m∈{0,1}∗m\in \{0,1\}^*m∈{0,1}∗ do:

    1. Compute (c,k)←Encapspk(1n)(c,k)\leftarrow Encaps_{pk}(1^n)(c,k)←Encapspk​(1n).
    2. Compute c′←Enck′(m)c'\leftarrow Enc_{k}^{'}(m)c′←Enck′​(m).
    3. Output the ciphertext <c,c′><c,c'><c,c′>.

  • DechyDec^{hy}Dechy: on input a private key sksksk and a ciphertext <c,c′><c,c'><c,c′> do:

    1. Compute k:=Decapssk(c)k:=Decaps_{sk}(c)k:=Decapssk​(c).
    2. Output the message m:=Deck′(c′)m:=Dec_{k}^{'}(c')m:=Deck′​(c′).

CDH/DDH-based encryption

El Gamal encryption

Let G\mathcal{G}G be a probabilistic polynomial-time algorithm that, on input 1n1^n1n, outputs a description of a cyclic group G\mathbb{G}G, its order qqq with ∣∣q∣∣=n||q||=n∣∣q∣∣=n, and a generator g∈Gg\in \mathbb{G}g∈G. Define the El Gamal encryption scheme as follows:

  • GenGenGen: on input 1n1^n1n run G(1n)\mathcal{G}(1^{n})G(1n) to obtain (G,q,g)(\mathbb{G},q,g)(G,q,g). Then choose a uniform x∈Zqx\in \mathbb{Z}_qx∈Zq​ and compute h:=gxh:=g^xh:=gx. The public key is <G,q,g,h><\mathbb{G},q,g,h><G,q,g,h> and the private key is <G,q,g,x><\mathbb{G},q,g,x><G,q,g,x>. The message space is G\mathbb{G}G.
  • EncEncEnc: on input a public key pk=<G,q,g,h>pk=<\mathbb{G},q,g,h>pk=<G,q,g,h> and a message m∈Gm\in \mathbb{G}m∈G, choose a uniform y∈Zqy\in \mathbb{Z}_qy∈Zq​ and output the ciphertext <gy,hy⋅m><g^{y},h^{y}\cdot m><gy,hy⋅m>.
  • DecDecDec: on input a private key sk=<G,q,g,x>sk=<\mathbb{G},q,g,x>sk=<G,q,g,x> and a ciphertext <c1,c2><c_{1},c_{2}><c1​,c2​>, output m^:=c2/c1x\hat{m}:=c_{2}/c_{1}^{x}m^:=c2​/c1x​.

If the DDH problem is hard relative to G\mathcal{G}G, then the El Gamal encryption scheme is CPA-secure, but it is not CCA-secure!

Some implementation issues:

  • It is common for these parameters generated by GenGenGen to be fixed once for all, and then shared by multiple receivers. Sharing parameters in this way \textit{does not impact security}.
  • The group order qqq is generally chosen to be prime. And elliptic curves are one popular choice.
  • The message space is a group G\mathbb{G}G rather than bit-strings. So the messages need to be encoded as group elements before encryption, and decoded after decryption.

DDH-based key encapsulation

Let G\mathcal{G}G be a probabilistic polynomial-time algorithm that, on input 1n1^n1n, outputs a description of a cyclic group G\mathbb{G}G, its order qqq with ∣∣q∣∣=n||q||=n∣∣q∣∣=n, and a generator g∈Gg\in \mathbb{G}g∈G. Define a KEM as follows:

  • GenGenGen: on input 1n1^n1n run G(1n)\mathcal{G}(1^{n})G(1n) to obtain (G,q,g)(\mathbb{G},q,g)(G,q,g). Then choose a uniform x∈Zqx\in \mathbb{Z}_qx∈Zq​ and compute h:=gxh:=g^xh:=gx. Also specify a function H:G→{0,1}ℓ(n)H:\mathbb{G}\rightarrow \{0,1\}^{\ell (n)}H:G→{0,1}ℓ(n) for some function ℓ\ellℓ. The public key is <G,q,g,h,H><\mathbb{G},q,g,h,H><G,q,g,h,H> and the private key is <G,q,g,x><\mathbb{G},q,g,x><G,q,g,x>.
  • EncapsEncapsEncaps: on input a public key pk=<G,q,g,h,H>pk=<\mathbb{G},q,g,h,H>pk=<G,q,g,h,H>, choose a uniform y∈Zqy\in \mathbb{Z}_qy∈Zq​ and output the ciphertext gyg^{y}gy and the key H(hy)H(h^{y})H(hy).
  • DecapsDecapsDecaps: on input a private key sk=<G,q,g,x>sk=<\mathbb{G},q,g,x>sk=<G,q,g,x> and a ciphertext c∈Gc\in \mathbb{G}c∈G, output the key H(cx)H(c^{x})H(cx).

If the gap-CDH problem (based on CDH problem, additionally give access to an oracle O\mathcal{O}O that O(U,V)\mathcal{O}(U,V)O(U,V) returns 1 when V=UyV=U^yV=Uy) is hard relative to G\mathcal{G}G, and HHH is modeled as a random oracle (an ideal model that treats a cryptographic hash function HHH as a truly random function), then the above construction is a CCA-secure KEM.

DHIES/ECIES

Let G\mathcal{G}G be a probabilistic polynomial-time algorithm that, on input 1n1^n1n, outputs a description of a cyclic group G\mathbb{G}G, its order qqq with ∣∣q∣∣=n||q||=n∣∣q∣∣=n, and a generator g∈Gg\in \mathbb{G}g∈G. Let ΠE=(Enc′,Dec′)\Pi_{E}=(Enc',Dec')ΠE​=(Enc′,Dec′) be a private-key encryption scheme, and let ΠM=(Mac,Vrfy)\Pi_{M}=(Mac,Vrfy)ΠM​=(Mac,Vrfy) be a message authentication code. Define a public-key encryption scheme as follows:

  • GenGenGen: On input 1n1^n1n run G(1n)\mathcal{G}(1^{n})G(1n) to obtain (G,q,g)(\mathbb{G},q,g)(G,q,g). Choose a uniform x∈Zqx\in \mathbb{Z}_qx∈Zq​, set h:=gxh:=g^xh:=gx, and specify a function H:G→{0,1}2nH:\mathbb{G}\rightarrow \{0,1\}^{2n}H:G→{0,1}2n. The public key is <G,q,g,h,H><\mathbb{G},q,g,h,H><G,q,g,h,H> and the private key is <G,q,g,x,H><\mathbb{G},q,g,x,H><G,q,g,x,H>.
  • EncEncEnc: On input a public key pk=<G,q,g,h,H>pk=<\mathbb{G},q,g,h,H>pk=<G,q,g,h,H>, choose a uniform y∈Zqy\in \mathbb{Z}_qy∈Zq​ and set kE∣∣kM:=H(hy)k_{E}||k_{M}:=H(h^{y})kE​∣∣kM​:=H(hy). Compute c′=EnckE′(m)c'=Enc_{k_{E}}^{'}(m)c′=EnckE​′​(m) and output the ciphertext <gy,c′,MackM(c′)><g^{y},c',Mac_{k_{M}}(c')><gy,c′,MackM​​(c′)>.
  • DecDecDec: On input a private key sk=<G,q,g,x,H>sk=<\mathbb{G},q,g,x,H>sk=<G,q,g,x,H> and a ciphertext <c,c′,t><c,c',t><c,c′,t>, output failure if c∉Gc\notin \mathbb{G}c∈/​G. Else, compute kE∣∣kM:=H(cx)k_{E}||k_{M}:=H(c^{x})kE​∣∣kM​:=H(cx). If VrfykM(c′,t)≠1Vrfy_{k_{M}}(c',t)\ne 1VrfykM​​(c′,t)​=1 then output failure, otherwise output DeckE′(c′)Dec_{k_{E}}^{'}(c')DeckE​′​(c′).

When the group G\mathbb{G}G is a cyclic subgroup of a finite field, this encryption scheme is called the Diffie-Hellman Integrated Encryption Scheme (DHIES). And When G\mathbb{G}G is an elliptic-curve group, it is called the Elliptic Curve Integrated Encryption Scheme (ECIES).

Let ΠE\Pi_{E}ΠE​ be a CPA-secure private-key encryption scheme, and let ΠM\Pi_{M}ΠM​ be a strongly secure message authentication code. If the gap-CDH problem is hard relative to G\mathcal{G}G, and HHH is modeled as a random oracle, then the above construction is a CCA-secure public-key encryption scheme.

RSA encryption

Plain RSA

Using RSA generation algorithm \ref{alg:rsa_gen}, define the plain RSA encryption scheme as follows:

  • GenGenGen: on input 1n1^n1n run GenRSA(1n)GenRSA(1^{n})GenRSA(1n) to obtain NNN, eee and ddd. The public key is <N,e><N,e><N,e> and the private key is <N,d><N,d><N,d>.
  • EncEncEnc: on input a public key pk=<N,e>pk=<N,e>pk=<N,e> and a message m∈ZN∗m\in \mathbb{Z}_{N}^{*}m∈ZN∗​, compute the ciphertext c:=[me mod N]c:=[m^{e}~mod~N]c:=[me mod N]
  • DecDecDec: on input a private key sk=<N,d>sk=<N,d>sk=<N,d> and a ciphertext c∈ZN∗c\in \mathbb{Z}_{N}^{*}c∈ZN∗​, compute the message m:=[cd mod N]m:=[c^{d}~mod~N]m:=[cd mod N].

Plain RSA encryption is deterministic and so it is not CPA-secure!

Padded RSA & PKCS #1 v1.5

Using RSA generation algorithm \ref{alg:rsa_gen}, and let ℓ\ellℓ be a function with ℓ(n)≤2n−4\ell (n)\le 2n-4ℓ(n)≤2n−4 for all nnn. Define a public-key encryption scheme as follows:

  • GenGenGen: on input 1n1^n1n run GenRSA(1n)GenRSA(1^{n})GenRSA(1n) to obtain NNN, eee and ddd. The public key is <N,e><N,e><N,e> and the private key is <N,d><N,d><N,d>.
  • EncEncEnc: on input a public key pk=<N,e>pk=<N,e>pk=<N,e> and a message m∈{0,1}∣∣N∣∣−ℓ(n)−2m\in \{0,1\}^{||N||-\ell (n)-2}m∈{0,1}∣∣N∣∣−ℓ(n)−2, choose a uniform string r∈{0,1}ℓ(n)r\in \{0,1\}^{\ell (n)}r∈{0,1}ℓ(n) and interpret m^:=r∣∣m\hat{m}:=r||mm^:=r∣∣m as an element of ZN∗\mathbb{Z}_{N}^{*}ZN∗​. Output the ciphertext c:=[m^e mod N]c:=[\hat{m}^{e}~mod~N]c:=[m^e mod N].
  • DecDecDec: on input a private key sk=<N,d>sk=<N,d>sk=<N,d> and a ciphertext c∈ZN∗c\in \mathbb{Z}_{N}^{*}c∈ZN∗​, compute m^:=[cd mod N]\hat{m}:=[c^{d}~mod~N]m^:=[cd mod N] and output the ∣∣N∣∣−ℓ(n)−2||N||-\ell (n)-2∣∣N∣∣−ℓ(n)−2 least-significant bits of m^\hat{m}m^.

The RSA laboratories Public-Key Cryptography Standard (PKCS) #1 version 1.5, utilizes a varient of padded RSA encryption. Let kkk denote an integer satisfying 28(k−1)≤N≤28k2^{8(k-1)}\le N \le 2^{8k}28(k−1)≤N≤28k (the length of NNN in bytes). Messages mmm to be encrypted are assumed to be a multiple of 8 bits long and can have length anywhere from one to k−11k-11k−11 bytes. Encryption of a message mmm is computed as [(0x00∣∣0x02∣∣r∣∣0x00∣∣m)e mod N][(0x00||0x02||r||0x00||m)^{e}~mod~N][(0x00∣∣0x02∣∣r∣∣0x00∣∣m)e mod N], where rrr is randomly generated.

Unfortunately, PKCS #1 v1.5 as specified is not CPA-secure because it allows using random padding that is too short. If we force rrr to be roughly half the length of NNN, then it is reasonable to \textit{conjecture} that the encryption scheme in PKCS #1 v1.5 is CPA-secure. Also, PKCS #1 v1.5 is not CCA-secure.

OAEP & RSA PKCS #1 v2.0

Let GenRSAGenRSAGenRSA be as in the previous sections, and ℓ(n),k0(n),k1(n)\ell(n),k_{0}(n),k_{1}(n)ℓ(n),k0​(n),k1​(n) be integer-valued functions with k0(n),k1(n)=Θ(n)k_{0}(n),k_{1}(n)=\Theta(n)k0​(n),k1​(n)=Θ(n) and that ℓ(n)+k0(n)+k1(n)\ell(n)+k_{0}(n)+k_{1}(n)ℓ(n)+k0​(n)+k1​(n) is less than the minimum bit-length of moduli output by GenRSA(1n)GenRSA(1^{n})GenRSA(1n). Let G:{0,1}k0→{0,1}ℓ+k1G:\{0,1\}^{k_{0}}\rightarrow \{0,1\}^{\ell+k_{1}}G:{0,1}k0​→{0,1}ℓ+k1​ and H:{0,1}ℓ+k1→{0,1}k0H:\{0,1\}^{\ell+k_{1}}\rightarrow \{0,1\}^{k_{0}}H:{0,1}ℓ+k1​→{0,1}k0​ be functions. Construct the RSA-OAEP encryption scheme as follows:

  • GenGenGen: on input 1n1^n1n run GenRSA(1n)GenRSA(1^{n})GenRSA(1n) to obtain NNN, eee and ddd. The public key is <N,e><N,e><N,e> and the private key is <N,d><N,d><N,d>.
  • EncEncEnc: on input a public key <N,e><N,e><N,e> and a message m∈{0,1}ℓm\in \{0,1\}^{\ell}m∈{0,1}ℓ, set m′:=m∣∣0k1m':=m||0^{k_{1}}m′:=m∣∣0k1​ and choose a uniform r∈{0,1}k0r\in \{0,1\}^{k_{0}}r∈{0,1}k0​. Then compute s:=m′ XOR G(r)s:=m'~XOR~G(r)s:=m′ XOR G(r), t:=r XOR H(s)t:=r~XOR~H(s)t:=r XOR H(s), and set m^:=s∣∣t\hat{m}:=s||tm^:=s∣∣t. Output the ciphertext c:=[m^e mod N]c:=[\hat{m}^{e}~mod~N]c:=[m^e mod N].
  • DecDecDec: on input a private key <N,d><N,d><N,d> and a ciphertext c∈ZN∗c\in \mathbb{Z}_{N}^{*}c∈ZN∗​, compute m^:=[cd mod N]\hat{m}:=[c^{d}~mod~N]m^:=[cd mod N]. If ∣∣m^∣∣>ℓ+k0+k1||\hat{m}||>\ell +k_{0}+k_{1}∣∣m^∣∣>ℓ+k0​+k1​, output error. Otherwise, parse m^\hat{m}m^ as s∣∣ts||ts∣∣t with s∈{0,1}ℓ+k1s\in \{0,1\}^{\ell+k_{1}}s∈{0,1}ℓ+k1​ and t∈{0,1}k0t\in \{0,1\}^{k_{0}}t∈{0,1}k0​. Compute r:=H(s) XOR tr:=H(s)~XOR~tr:=H(s) XOR t and m′:=G(r) XOR sm':=G(r)~XOR~sm′:=G(r) XOR s. If the least-significant k1k_1k1​ bits of m′m'm′ are not all 0, output error. Otherwise, output the ℓ\ellℓ most-significant bits of m^\hat{m}m^.

The RSA-OAEP encryption scheme is CCA-secure. But the encryption scheme should ensure that the time to return an error is identical regardless of where the error occurs, otherwise this information can be used as side-channel information in CCA.

密码学：哈希函数

发表于 2020-10-20 阅读次数：
本文字数： 10k 阅读时长 ≈ 9 分钟

Basic concepts

Definition

A hash function (with output length ℓ\ellℓ) is a pair of probabilistic polynomial-time algorithms (Gen,H)(Gen,H)(Gen,H) satisfying the following:

  • GenGenGen is a probabilistic algorithm that takes as input a security parameter 1n1^n1n and outputs a key sss. We assume that 1n1^n1n is implicit in sss.
  • HHH takes as input a key sss and a string x∈{0,1}∗x\in \{0,1\}^*x∈{0,1}∗ and outputs a string Hs(x)∈{0,1}ℓ(n)H^{s}(x)\in \{0,1\}^{\ell(n)}Hs(x)∈{0,1}ℓ(n) (nnn is the security parameter implicit in sss).

In general case, the function takes as input strings of arbitrary length. If HsH^sHs is defined only for inputs x∈{0,1}ℓ′(n)x\in\{0,1\}^{\ell '(n)}x∈{0,1}ℓ′(n) and ℓ′(n)>ℓ(n)\ell '(n)>\ell(n)ℓ′(n)>ℓ(n), then we say that (Gen,H)(Gen,H)(Gen,H) is a fixed-length hash function for inputs of length ℓ′\ell 'ℓ′. In this case, HHH is also called a compression function.

Collision resistance

First we define an collision-finding experiment Hash−collA,π(n)Hash-coll_{\mathcal{A},\pi}(n)Hash−collA,π​(n) for a hash function Π=(Gen,H)\Pi=(Gen,H)Π=(Gen,H), an adversary A\mathcal{A}A and a security parameter nnn:

  1. A key sss is generated by running Gen(1n)Gen(1^n)Gen(1n).
  2. The adversary A\mathcal{A}A is given sss and outputs x,x′x,x'x,x′.
  3. The output of the experiment is defined to be 1 if and only if x≠x′x\ne x'x​=x′ and Hs(x)=Hs(x′)H^s(x)=H^s(x')Hs(x)=Hs(x′). In such a case we say that A\mathcal{A}A has found a collision.

A hash function Π=(Gen,H)\Pi=(Gen,H)Π=(Gen,H) is collision resistant if for all probabilistic polynomial-time adversaries A\mathcal{A}A there is a negligible function neglneglnegl such that

Pr[Hash−collA,π(n)=1]≤negl(n)Pr[Hash-coll_{\mathcal{A},\pi}(n)=1]\le negl(n) Pr[Hash−collA,π​(n)=1]≤negl(n)

Unkeyed hash functions

Cryptographic hash functions used in practice generally have a fixed output length and are usually unkeyed, meaning that the hash function is just a fixed function H:{0,1}∗→{0,1}ℓH:\{0,1\}^*\rightarrow \{0,1\}^\ellH:{0,1}∗→{0,1}ℓ. Although this is problematic theoretically since HHH must have a collision pair, the unkeyed cryptographic hash functions used in the real world are collision resistant for all practical purposes. It is due to the fact that colliding pairs are unknown and computationally difficult to find even though they must exist.

In proofs of security for the construction based on collision resistance of a hash function, we just assume that any efficient ways to find a collision in HHH can be used by the adversaries.

Weaker notions of security

In some applications, it suffices to rely on security requirements weaker than collision resistance. These include:

  • Second-preimage or target-collision resistance: if given sss and a uniform xxx, it is infeasible for a PPT adversary to find x′≠xx'\ne xx′​=x such that Hs(x′)=Hs(x)H^s(x')=H^s(x)Hs(x′)=Hs(x). Any hash function that is collision resistant is also second preimage resistant.
  • Preimage resistance: if given sss and a uniform yyy, it is infeasible for a PPT adversary to find a value xxx such that Hs(x)=yH^s(x)=yHs(x)=y (this essentially means that HsH^sHs is one-way).

Domain extension: the Merkle-Damgard transform

Hash functions are often constructed by first designing a collision-resistant compression function handling fixed-length inputs, and then using domain extension to handle arbitrary-length inputs. The Merkle-Damgard transform is a common approach for extending a compression function to a full-fledged hash function, while maintaining the collision-resistance property of the former.

Let (Gen,h)(Gen,h)(Gen,h) be a fixed-length hash function for inputs of length 2n2n2n and with output length nnn. Construct hash function (Gen,H)(Gen,H)(Gen,H) as follows:

  • GenGenGen: a probabilistic algorithm that takes as input a security parameter 1n1^n1n and outputs a key sss
  • HHH: on input a key sss and a string x∈{0,1}∗x\in \{0,1\}^*x∈{0,1}∗ of length L<2nL<2^nL<2n, do the following:
    1. Set B=⌈Ln⌉B=\lceil \frac{L}{n}\rceilB=⌈nL​⌉ (i.e., the number of blocks in xxx). Pad xxx with zeros so its length is a multiple of nnn. Parse the padded result as the sequence of n-bit blocks x1,…,xBx_1,\dots,x_Bx1​,…,xB​. Set xB+1=Lx_{B+1}=LxB+1​=L, where LLL is encoded as an n-bit string.
    2. Set z0=0nz_0=0^nz0​=0n (this is also called the IV).
    3. For i=1,…,B+1i=1,\dots,B+1i=1,…,B+1, compute zi=hs(zi−1∣∣xi)z_i=h^s(z_{i-1}||x_i)zi​=hs(zi−1​∣∣xi​).
    4. Output zB+1z_{B+1}zB+1​.

The above construction is illustrated as the following figure:

Message authentication using hash functions

Hash-and-MAC

Let Π=(Mac,Vrfy)\Pi=(Mac,Vrfy)Π=(Mac,Vrfy) be a MAC for messages of length ℓ(n)\ell(n)ℓ(n), and let ΠH=(GenH,H)\Pi_H=(Gen_H,H)ΠH​=(GenH​,H) be a hash function with output length ℓ(n)\ell(n)ℓ(n). Construct a MAC Π′=(Gen′,Mac′,Vrfy′)\Pi'=(Gen',Mac',Vrfy')Π′=(Gen′,Mac′,Vrfy′) for arbitrary-length messages as follows:

  • Gen′Gen'Gen′: on input 1n1^n1n, choose uniform k∈{0,1}nk\in \{0,1\}^nk∈{0,1}n and run GenH(1n)Gen_{H}(1^n)GenH​(1n) to obtain sss; the key is k′=<k,s>k'=<k,s>k′=<k,s>.
  • Mac′Mac'Mac′: on input a key <k,s><k,s><k,s> and a message m∈{0,1}∗m\in \{0,1\}^*m∈{0,1}∗, output t←Mack(Hs(m))t\leftarrow Mac_k(H^s(m))t←Mack​(Hs(m)).
  • Vrfy′Vrfy'Vrfy′: on input a key <k,s><k,s><k,s>, a message m∈{0,1}∗m\in \{0,1\}^*m∈{0,1}∗, and a MAC tag ttt, output 1 if and only if Vrfyk(Hs(m),t)=1Vrfy_k(H^s(m),t)=1Vrfyk​(Hs(m),t)=1.

If Π\PiΠ is a secure MAC for messages of length ℓ\ellℓ and ΠH\Pi_HΠH​ is collision resistant, then the above construction is a secure MAC for arbitrary-length messages.

HMAC

If HHH is constructed using the Merkle-Damg\aa{}rd transform (and the most real-world hash functions are), then a MAC designed in this way is completely insecure (why?). Instead, two layers of hashing is used.

Let (GenH,H)(Gen_H,H)(GenH​,H) be a hash function constructed by applying the Merkle-Damg\aa{}rd transform to a compression function (GenH,h)(Gen_H,h)(GenH​,h) taking inputs of length n+n′n+n'n+n′. Let ipadipadipad and opadopadopad be fixed constants of length n′n'n′. Define a MAC as follows:
\begin{itemize}

  • GenGenGen: on input 1n1^n1n, run GenH(1n)Gen_H(1^n)GenH​(1n) to obtain a key sss. Also choose uniform k∈{0,1}n′k\in \{0,1\}^{n'}k∈{0,1}n′. Output the key <s,k><s,k><s,k>.
  • MacMacMac: on input a key <s,k><s,k><s,k> and a message m∈{0,1}∗m\in \{0,1\}^*m∈{0,1}∗, output t:=Hs((k xor opad)∣∣Hs((k xor ipad)∣∣m))t:=H^s((k~xor~opad)||H^s((k~xor~ipad)||m))t:=Hs((k xor opad)∣∣Hs((k xor ipad)∣∣m)).
  • VrfyVrfyVrfy: on input a key <s,k><s,k><s,k>, a message m∈{0,1}∗m\in \{0,1\}^*m∈{0,1}∗, and a tag ttt, output 1 if and only if t=Hs((k xor opad)∣∣Hs((k xor ipad)∣∣m))t=H^s((k~xor~opad)||H^s((k~xor~ipad)||m))t=Hs((k xor opad)∣∣Hs((k xor ipad)∣∣m)).

The HMAC construction is illustrated as the following figure:

Generic attacks on hash functions

Birthday attacks

The collision-finding algorithm we have described is often called a birthday attack.The birthday problem is the following: if qqq people are in a room, what is the probability that two of them have the same birthday? (Assume birthdays are uniformly and independently distributed among the 365 days of a non-leap year.)

For y1,…,yqy_1,\dots,y_qy1​,…,yq​ chosen uniformly in {1,…,N}\{1,\dots,N\}{1,…,N}, the probability of a collision is roughly 1/2 when q=Θ(N1/2)q=\Theta(N^{1/2})q=Θ(N1/2). So, for a hash function to resist collision-finding attacks that run in time TTT, the output length of the hash function needs to be at least 2log⁡T2\log T2logT bits.

Small-space birthday attacks

The small-space birthday attack has similar time complexity and success probability as birthday attacks, but require drastically reduced memory requirements (use constant memory). The attack begins by choosing a random value x0x_0x0​ and then computing xi:=H(xi−1)x_i:=H(x_{i-1})xi​:=H(xi−1​) and x2i:=H(H(x2(i−1)))x_{2i}:=H(H(x_{2(i-1)}))x2i​:=H(H(x2(i−1)​)) for i=1,2,…i=1,2,\dotsi=1,2,…. In each step the values xix_ixi​ and x2ix_{2i}x2i​ are compared; if they are equal then there is a collision somewhere in the sequence x0,x1,…,x2i−1x_0,x_1,\dots,x_{2i-1}x0​,x1​,…,x2i−1​.

Additional application of hash functions

  • Fingerprinting & Deduplication:

    When using a collision-resistant hash function HHH, the hash of a file H(x)H(x)H(x) can be used as a unique identifier of the file xxx. One can check the hashes of two files to determine whether they are equal. This idea is used in many applications like virus fingerprinting, file deduplication, P2P file sharing, etc.

  • Password hashing:

    The user’s passward pwpwpw is stored by a hash of the password H(pw)H(pw)H(pw) instead of a password itself. To prevent exhaustive decryption from an attacker, one way is to use “slow” hash functions (i.e., compute HI(pw)H^{I}(pw)HI(pw) for I>>1I>>1I>>1), and another way is to introduce a salt (i.e., a long random value sss unique to the user)

  • Key derivation:

    A key-derivation function provides a way to obtain a uniformly distributed string from any distribution with high (computational) min-entropy.

  • Commitment scheme:

    A commitment scheme allows one party to “commit” to a message mmm by sending a commitment value comcomcom, with comcomcom reveals nothing about mmm and comcomcom cannot later “open” as two different messages. To commit to a message mmm, the sender chooses uniform r∈{0,1}nr \in \{0, 1\}^nr∈{0,1}n and outputs com:=H(m∣∣r)com := H(m||r)com:=H(m∣∣r).

Practical applications

Hash function from block ciphers

It is possible to build a collision-resistant compression function from a block cipher. One of the most common ways is via the Davies-Meyer construction.

Let FFF be a block cipher with nnn-bit key length and ℓ\ellℓ-bit block length. The compression function h:{0,1}n+ℓ→{0,1}ℓh:\{0,1\}^{n+\ell}\rightarrow \{0,1\}^{\ell}h:{0,1}n+ℓ→{0,1}ℓ is defined as h(k,x)=Fk(x)⊕xh(k,x)=F_{k}(x)\oplus xh(k,x)=Fk​(x)⊕x.

If FFF is modeled as \textit{an ideal cipher}, then the Davies–Meyer construction yields a collision-resistant compression function. However, when instantiating the Davies-Meyer construction with concrete block ciphers, the ciphers should be designed specially for this purpose (block ciphers designed for encryption like DES and AES should not be used).

MD5

MD5 is a hash function with a 128-bit output length. Today, the collisions in MD5 can be found within one minute. So MD5 should not be used anywhere cryptographic security is needed.

The detail of MD5 algorithm can refer to:

  • https://www.zhihu.com/question/278134292
  • https://blog.csdn.net/goodnameused/article/details/81068697

SHA family

The Secure Hash Algorithm (SHA) refers to a series of cryptographic hash functions standardized by NIST.

SHA-1 has a 160-bit output length. Theoretical analysis over the past few years indicates that collisions in SHA-1 can be found using significantly fewer than the 2802^{80}280 hash-function evaluations, and it is conjectured that a collision will be found soon. So it is recommended to be replaced by more secure hash algorithms. The details of SHA-1 can refer to: https://blog.csdn.net/cmqwan/article/details/82414954

SHA-2 is a group of hash functions includes SHA-224, SHA-256, SHA-384, SHA-512, etc. SHA-2 is recommended to use in applications. The principle of SHA-256 can refer to: https://blog.csdn.net/jerry81333/article/details/78566418.

SHA-3(Keccak) was chosen as the next-generation replacement of SHA-2. The structure of SHA-3 is very different from SHA-1 and SHA-2. Refer to the following pages for details: https://blog.csdn.net/chengqiuming/article/details/82819769, https://blog.csdn.net/BlackNight168/article/details/82952489

References

  1. Introduction to Modern Cryptography, Second Edition.
  2. Understanding Cryptography: A Textbook for Students and Practitioners (Chinese Version).

密码学：消息验证码

发表于 2020-10-20 阅读次数：
本文字数： 15k 阅读时长 ≈ 14 分钟

Basic concepts

Message integrity

Message integrity (Message authentication): each party should be able to identify when a message it receives was sent by the party claiming to send it, and it was not modified in transit.

E.g. A bank should make sure a transfer request is sent by a legitimate user, and the received request should not be modified.

Remember that encryption does not privide any integrity unless it is specifically designed with that purpose!

E.g. For a stream cipher, the attacker can filp one or more bits of the ciphertext ccc to modify the decrypted plaintext. Since the attacker do not know the plaintext, it does not contradict the concept of secrecy.

Message Authentication Codes (MAC)

Definition

A message authentication code (MAC) consists of three probabilistic polynomial-time algorithms (Gen,Mac,Vrfy)(Gen,Mac,Vrfy)(Gen,Mac,Vrfy) such that

  1. The key-generation algorithm GenGenGen takes as input the security parameter 1n1^n1n and outputs a key kkk with ∣k∣≥n|k|\ge n∣k∣≥n.
  2. The tag-generation algorithm MacMacMac takes as input a key kkk and a message m∈{0,1}∗m\in \{0,1\}^*m∈{0,1}∗, and outputs a tag ttt. We write it as t←Mack(m)t\leftarrow Mac_{k}(m)t←Mack​(m) since the algorithm might be randomized.
  3. The deterministic verification algorithm VrfyVrfyVrfy takes as input a key kkk, a message mmm and a tag ttt. It outputs a bit bbb, with b=1b=1b=1 meaning valid and b=0b=0b=0 meaning invalid. We write this as b:=Vrfyk(m,t)b:=Vrfy_{k}(m,t)b:=Vrfyk​(m,t).

It is required that for every nnn, every key kkk output by Gen(1n)Gen(1^{n})Gen(1n) and every m∈{0,1}∗m\in \{0,1\}^*m∈{0,1}∗, it holds that Vrfyk(m,Mack(m))=1Vrfy_{k}(m,Mac_{k}(m))=1Vrfyk​(m,Mack​(m))=1.

Security of MACs

The message authentication experiment Mac-forge_{\cal{A},\pi}(n):

  1. A key kkk is generated by running Gen(1n)Gen(1^{n})Gen(1n).
  2. The adversary \cal{A} is given input 1n1^n1n and oracle access to Mack(⋅)Mac_{k}(\cdot)Mack​(⋅). The adversary eventually outputs (m,t)(m,t)(m,t) (mmm could be any messages of its choice). Let \cal{Q} denote the set of all queries that \cal{A} asked its oracle.
  3. \cal{A} succeeds if and only if (1) Vrfyk(m,t)=1Vrfy_{k}(m,t)=1Vrfyk​(m,t)=1 and (2) m \notin \cal{Q}. In that case the output of the experiment is defined to be 1.

A message authentication code Π=(Gen,Mac,Vrfy)\Pi =(Gen, Mac, Vrfy)Π=(Gen,Mac,Vrfy) is existentilly unforgeable under an adaptive chosen-message attack, or just secure, if for all probabilistic polynomial-time adversaries \cal{A}, there is a negligible function neglneglnegl such that

Pr[Mac-forge_{\cal{A},\pi}(n)=1]\le negl(n)

This definition of security is strong in two respects. First, the adversary is allowed to request MACMACMAC tags for any messages of its choice. Second, the adversary is considered to have broken the scheme if it can output a valid tag on any previously unauthenticated message.

By making the definition of security for MACs as strong as possible, we ensure that secure MACs can be used for a wide range of purposes without worring about compatibility of the MAC with the semantics of the application.

Remember the MAC itself offers no protection against replay attacks! To prevent replay attacks, two common techniques are used:

  • Sequence numbers (or counters): the communicating users maintain(synchronize) a state. It can be problematic when users communicate over a lossy channel.
  • Time stamps: the sender prepends the current time TTT to the message before authenticating, and sends TTT along with the mesage and the and the resulting tag ttt. The receiver verifies that ttt is a valid tag for T∣∣mT||mT∣∣m and TTT is within acceptable clock skew from current time. This method requires maintaining closely synchronized clocks. And a replay attack can still take place if it is done quickly enough.

Strong MACs

Consider a modified experiment Mac−sforgeMac-sforgeMac−sforge that defined the same way as Mac−forgeMac-forgeMac−forge, except that the set \cal{Q} contains pairs of oracle queries and their associated responses (i.e. (m,t)\in \cal{Q}). The adversary \cal{A} succeeds if and only if \cal{A} outputs (m,t)(m,t)(m,t) such that Vrfyk(m,t)=1Vrfy_{k}(m,t)=1Vrfyk​(m,t)=1 and (m,t)\notin \cal{Q}.

A message authentication code Π=(Gen,Mac,Vrfy)\Pi=(Gen,Mac,Vrfy)Π=(Gen,Mac,Vrfy) is strongly secure, or a strong MAC, if for all probabilistic polynomial-time adversaries \cal{A}, there is a negligible function neglneglnegl such that:

Pr[Mac-sforge_{\cal{A},\pi}(n)=1]\le negl(n)

Let Π=(Gen,Mac,Vrfy)\Pi=(Gen,Mac,Vrfy)Π=(Gen,Mac,Vrfy) be a secure MAC that uses canonical verification (the receiver re-compute the tag and check for equality). Then Π\PiΠ is a strong MAC. (Attention that the definition of the MAC do not have any restriciton to how VrfyVrfyVrfy algorithm works.)

A potential timing attack (an example of side channel attack): Consider an adversary who can send message/tag pairs to the receiver. The adversary can learn not only whether the receiver accepts or not, but also the time to make decisions. If there is a MAC using canonical verification, the time to reject differs depending on the position of the first unequal byte. The attacker can send (m,t0),⋯ ,(m,t255)(m,t_{0}),\cdots,(m,t_{255})(m,t0​),⋯,(m,t255​) to the receiver, where tjt_{j}tj​ is a string with the first iii bytes set correctly and the (i+1)st(i+1)st(i+1)st byte equal to jjj. The tag with slightly longer time for rejection has the correct (i+1)st(i+1)st(i+1)st byte.

MAC verification should use time-independent string comparison that always compares all bytes!

Construct secure MACs

A fixed-length MAC

Construction

Let FFF be a pseudorandom function. Define a fixed-length MAC for messages of length nnn as follows:

  • Mac: on input a key k∈{0,1}nk\in \{0,1\}^nk∈{0,1}n and a message m∈{0,1}nm\in \{0,1\}^nm∈{0,1}n, output the tag t:=Fk(m)t:=F_{k}(m)t:=Fk​(m). (If ∣m∣≠∣k∣|m|\ne |k|∣m∣​=∣k∣ then output nothing.)
  • Vrfy: on input a key k∈{0,1}nk\in \{0,1\}^nk∈{0,1}n, a message m∈{0,1}nm\in \{0,1\}^nm∈{0,1}n and a tag t∈{0,1}nt\in \{0,1\}^nt∈{0,1}n, output 1 if and only if t=Fk(m)t=F_{k}(m)t=Fk​(m). (If ∣m∣≠∣k∣|m|\ne |k|∣m∣​=∣k∣ then output 0.)

If F is a pseudorandom function, then the above construction is a secure fixed-length MAC for messages of length n.

Proof

Consider the MAC Π~\tilde{\Pi}Π~ using a truly random function fff instead of pseudorandom function FkF_{k}Fk​. For any message m\notin \cal{Q}, the value t=f(m)t=f(m)t=f(m) is uniformly distributed in {0,1}n\{0,1\}^n{0,1}n from the view of adversary \cal{A}, so we can get:

Pr[Mac-forge_{\cal{A},\tilde{\pi}}(n)=1]\le 2^{-n}

Then construct a distinguisher DDD that is given input 1n1^n1n and access to an oracle \cal{O}:\{0,1\}^{n}\rightarrow \{0,1\}^{n}. (1) Run \cal{A}(1^{n}). Whenever \cal{A} queries its MAC oracle on a message mmm, \cal{A} obtain a response ttt. (2) When \cal{A} outputs (m,t)(m,t)(m,t) at the end of its execution, query \cal{O} with mmm and obtain response t^\hat{t}t^. If t^=t\hat{t}=tt^=t and \cal{A} never queried its MAC oracle on mmm, then output 1; otherwise output 0.

If DDD's oracle is a pseudorandom function, then the view of \cal{A} when run as a sub-routine by DDD is distributed identically to the view of \cal{A} in experiment Mac-forge_{\cal{A},\pi}(n). Therefore,

Pr[D^{F_{k}(\cdot)}(1^{n})=1]=Pr[Mac-forge_{\cal{A},\pi}(n)=1]

If DDD's oracle is a truly random function, then the view of \cal{A} when run as a sub-routine by DDD is distributed identically to the view of \cal{A} in experiment Mac-forge_{\cal{A},\tilde{\pi}}(n). Therefore,

Pr[D^{f(\cdot)}(1^{n})=1]=Pr[Mac-forge_{\cal{A},\tilde{\pi}}(n)=1]

Since FFF is a pseudorandom function and DDD runs in polynomial time, so there exists a negligible function neglneglnegl that

∣Pr[DFk(⋅)(1n)=1]−Pr[Df(⋅)(1n)=1]∣≤negl(n) |Pr[D^{F_{k}(\cdot)}(1^{n})=1]-Pr[D^{f(\cdot)}(1^{n})=1]|\le negl(n) ∣Pr[DFk​(⋅)(1n)=1]−Pr[Df(⋅)(1n)=1]∣≤negl(n)

Combining the above four equations, we finally get

Pr[Mac-forge_{\cal{A},\pi}(n)=1]\le 2^{-n}+negl(n)

which proves the theorem.

Domain extension for MACs

Construction

Let Π′=(Mac′,Vrfy′)\Pi'=(Mac',Vrfy')Π′=(Mac′,Vrfy′) be a fixed-length MAC for messages of length nnn. Define a MAC as follows:

  • MacMacMac: on input a key k∈{0,1}nk\in \{0,1\}^nk∈{0,1}n and a message m∈{0,1}∗m\in \{0,1\}^*m∈{0,1}∗ of nonzero length ℓ<2n/4\ell < 2^{n/4}ℓ<2n/4, parse mmm into ddd blocks m1,⋯ ,mdm_{1},\cdots,m_{d}m1​,⋯,md​, each of length n/4n/4n/4.(The final block is padded with 0s if necessary.) Choose a uniform identifier r∈{0,1}n/4r\in \{0,1\}^{n/4}r∈{0,1}n/4. For i=1,⋯ ,di=1,\cdots,di=1,⋯,d, compute ti←Mack′(r∣∣ℓ∣∣i∣∣mi)t_{i}\leftarrow Mac_{k}'(r||\ell||i||m_{i})ti​←Mack′​(r∣∣ℓ∣∣i∣∣mi​), where i,ℓi,\elli,ℓ are encoded as strings of length n/4n/4n/4. Output the tag t:=<r,t1,⋯ ,td>t:=<r,t_{1},\cdots,t_{d}>t:=<r,t1​,⋯,td​>.
  • VrfyVrfyVrfy: on input a key k∈{0,1}nk\in \{0,1\}^nk∈{0,1}n, a message m∈{0,1}∗m\in \{0,1\}^*m∈{0,1}∗ of nonzero length ℓ<2n/4\ell < 2^{n/4}ℓ<2n/4, and a tag t:=<r,t1,⋯ ,td′>t:=<r,t_{1},\cdots,t_{d'}>t:=<r,t1​,⋯,td′​>, parse mmm into ddd blocks m1,…,mdm_{1},\dots,m_{d}m1​,…,md​, each of length n/4n/4n/4.(The final block is padded with 0s if necessary.) Output 1 if and only if d′=dd'=dd′=d and Vrfyk′(r∣∣ℓ∣∣i∣∣mi,ti)=1Vrfy_{k}'(r||\ell||i||m_{i},t_{i})=1Vrfyk′​(r∣∣ℓ∣∣i∣∣mi​,ti​)=1 for 1≤i≤d1\le i \le d1≤i≤d.

If Π′\Pi'Π′ is a secure fixed-length MAC for messages of length nnn, then the following construction is a secure MAC (for arbitrary-length messages).

Note:

(1) iii is used for preventing block reordering attack (the attacker shuffles the order of blocks in an authenticated message).

(2) ℓ\ellℓ is intended to thwart truncation attack (the attacker drop blocks and corresponding tags from the end of the message).

(3) rrr aims at preventing “mix-and-match” attack (the attacker combines blocks from different messages).

Proof

Let RepeatRepeatRepeat denote the event that the same random identifier appears in two of the tags returned by the MAC oracle in experiment MAC-forge_{\cal{A},\pi'}(n). NewBlockNewBlockNewBlock denote the event that \cal{A} tries to output a valid tag on a block that was never previously authenticated by Mac′Mac'Mac′ in the course of answering \cal{A}'s Mac′Mac'Mac′ queries.

We have

\begin{align} Pr[MAC-forge_{\cal{A},\pi'}(n)=1]=& Pr[MAC-forge_{\cal{A},\pi'}(n)=1 \wedge Repeat] \notag \\ + & Pr[MAC-forge_{\cal{A},\pi'}(n)=1 \wedge \overline{Repeat}\wedge NewBlock] \notag \\ + & Pr[MAC-forge_{\cal{A},\pi'}(n)=1 \wedge \overline{Repeat}\wedge \overline{NewBlock}] \notag \\ \le & Pr[Repeat]+ \notag \\ & Pr[MAC-forge_{\cal{A},\pi'}(n)=1 \wedge NewBlock] + \notag \\ & Pr[MAC-forge_{\cal{A},\pi'}(n)=1 \wedge \overline{Repeat}\wedge \overline{NewBlock}] \end{align}

(1) Pr[Repeat]Pr[Repeat]Pr[Repeat] is negligible. Applying the “birthday bound” (search “birthday problem” for detail), we have Pr[Repeat]≤q(n)22n/4Pr[Repeat]\le \frac{q(n)^{2}}{2^{n/4}}Pr[Repeat]≤2n/4q(n)2​. Since \cal{A} makes only polynomially many queries (i.e., q(n)q(n)q(n) is polynomial), this value is negligible.

(2) Pr[MAC-forge_{\cal{A},\pi'}(n)=1 \wedge \overline{Repeat}\wedge \overline{NewBlock}]=0. If MAC-forge_{\cal{A},\pi'}(n)=1 and RepeatRepeatRepeat did not occur, then it must be the case that NewBlockNewBlockNewBlock happens. So Repeat‾\overline{Repeat}Repeat​ and NewBlock‾\overline{NewBlock}NewBlock can not occur at the same time.

(3) Pr[MAC-forge_{\cal{A},\pi'}(n)=1 \wedge NewBlock] is negligible. Construct a PPT adversary \cal{A}' attacks the fixed-length MAC Π\PiΠ. \cal{A'} runs as a subroutine of \cal{A}: answering the request by \cal{A} for a tag on mmm by choosing r←{0,1}n/4r\leftarrow \{0,1\}^{n/4}r←{0,1}n/4, parsing mmm and making necessary queries to Mack′(⋅)Mac_{k}'(\cdot)Mack′​(⋅); check whether NewBlockNewBlockNewBlock occur when \cal{A} outputs. If MAC-forge_{\cal{A},\pi'}(n)=1 then the tag for every block is valid; if NewBlockNewBlockNewBlock occurs then \cal{A}' outputs a block that was never previously authenticated. So \cal{A'} succeeds in outputting a valid forgery on a previously unauthenticated message with probability

Pr[Mac-forge_{\cal{A'},\pi}(n)=1]\ge Pr[MAC-forge_{\cal{A},\pi'}(n)=1 \wedge NewBlock]

The left-hand side is negligible, so proving the claim.

So from the above we have proved that Pr[MAC-forge_{\cal{A},\pi'}(n)=1] is negligible.

CBC-MAC

Let FFF be a pseudorandom function, and fix a length function ℓ>0\ell >0ℓ>0. The basic CBC-MAC construction is as follows:

  • MacMacMac: on input a key k∈{0,1}nk\in \{0,1\}^nk∈{0,1}n and a message mmm of length ℓ(n)⋅n\ell(n)\cdot nℓ(n)⋅n, parse mmm as m=m1,⋯ ,mℓm=m_{1},\cdots,m_{\ell}m=m1​,⋯,mℓ​ where each mim_{i}mi​ is of length nnn, and set t0:=0nt_{0}:=0^nt0​:=0n and ti:=Fk(Tk−1 XOR mi)t_{i}:=F_{k}(T_{k-1}~XOR~m_{i})ti​:=Fk​(Tk−1​ XOR mi​). Output tℓt_{\ell}tℓ​ as the tag.
  • VrfyVrfyVrfy: on input a key k∈{0,1}nk\in \{0,1\}^nk∈{0,1}n, a message mmm, a tag ttt, if mmm is not of length ℓ(n)⋅n\ell(n)\cdot nℓ(n)⋅n the output 0. Otherwise, output 1 if and only if t=Mack(m)t=Mac_{k}(m)t=Mack​(m).

Let ℓ\ellℓ be a polynomial. If FFF is a pseudorandom function, then the above construction is a secure MAC for messages of length ℓ(n)⋅n\ell(n)\cdot nℓ(n)⋅n. Note that t0:=0nt_{0}:=0^nt0​:=0n is crucial for security, and it is no longer secure when using a random t0t_0t0​.

For arbitrary-length messages, the fixed-length CBC-MAC can be modified in two ways:

  • Prepend the message mmm with its length ∣m∣|m|∣m∣ (encoded as an n-bit string) and compute basic CBC-MAC on the result.
  • Choose two independent, uniform keys k1∈{0,1}nk_1 \in \{0,1\}^nk1​∈{0,1}n and k2∈{0,1}nk_2 \in \{0,1\}^nk2​∈{0,1}n. Then to authenticate a message mmm, first compute the result ttt of basic CBC-MAC of mmm using k1k_1k1​, and the tag is computed as t^=Fk2(t)\hat{t}=F_{k_2}(t)t^=Fk2​​(t).

Authenticated encryption

Definitions

Let Π=(Gen,Enc,Dec)\Pi=(Gen,Enc,Dec)Π=(Gen,Enc,Dec) be a private-key encryption scheme, A\mathcal{A}A be an adversary, and nnn be the security parameter. The unforgeable encryption experiment Enc−ForgeA,π(n)Enc-Forge_{\mathcal{A},\pi}(n)Enc−ForgeA,π​(n) is defined as follows:

  1. Run Gen(1n)Gen(1^n)Gen(1n) to obtain a key kkk.
  2. The adversary A\mathcal{A}A is given input 1n1^n1n and access to an encryption oracle Enck(⋅)Enc_{k}(\cdot)Enck​(⋅). The adversary outputs a ciphertext ccc.
  3. Let m=Deck(c)m=Dec_{k}(c)m=Deck​(c), and let Q\mathcal{Q}Q denote the set of all queries that A\mathcal{A}A asked its encryption oracle. The output of the experiment is 1 if and only if (1) m≠errorm\ne \text{error}m​=error and (2) m∉Qm\notin \mathcal{Q}m∈/​Q.

A private-key encryption scheme Π\PiΠ is unforgeable if for all probabilistic polynomial-time adversaries A\mathcal{A}A, there is a negligible function neglneglnegl such that:

Pr[Enc−ForgeA,π(n)=1]≤negl(n)Pr[Enc-Forge_{\mathcal{A},\pi}(n)=1]\le negl(n) Pr[Enc−ForgeA,π​(n)=1]≤negl(n)

And a private-key encryption scheme Π\PiΠ is authenticated encryption scheme if it is CCA-secure and unforgeable.

Generic constructions

Let ΠE=(Enc,Dec)\Pi_{E}=(Enc,Dec)ΠE​=(Enc,Dec) be a CPA-secure encryption scheme and ΠM=(Mac,Vrfy)\Pi_{M}=(Mac,Vrfy)ΠM​=(Mac,Vrfy) denote a message authentication code, where key generation in both schemes simply involves choosing a uniform n-bit key. There are three natural approaches to combining encryption and message authentication using independent keys kEk_EkE​ and kMk_MkM​ for ΠE\Pi_{E}ΠE​ and ΠM\Pi_{M}ΠM​:

  1. Encrypt-and-authenticate: Given a message mmm, the transmitted value is <c,t><c,t><c,t> where

    c\leftarrow Enc_{k_E}(m)~\text{and}~t\leftarrow Mac_{k_M}(m)$$.

  2. Authenticate-then-encrypt: A MAC tag t←MACkM(m)t\leftarrow MAC_{k_M}(m)t←MACkM​​(m) is first computed, then m∣∣tm||tm∣∣t is encrypted and the resulting value EnckE(m∣∣t)Enc_{k_E}(m||t)EnckE​​(m∣∣t) is transmitted. This combination does not necessarily yield an authenticated encryption scheme, since the decryption has two steps.

  3. Encrypt-then-authenticate: The message mmm is first encrypted by c←EnckE(m)c\leftarrow Enc_{k_E}(m)c←EnckE​​(m), then the a MAC is computed by t←MackM(c)t\leftarrow Mac_{k_M}(c)t←MackM​​(c), and the ciphertext is <c,t><c,t><c,t>. Decryption of <c,t><c,t><c,t> is done by outputting error if VrfykM(c,t)≠1Vrfy_{k_M}(c,t)\ne 1VrfykM​​(c,t)​=1, and otherwise outputting DeckE(c)Dec_{k_E}(c)DeckE​​(c).

If ΠE\Pi_EΠE​ is a CPA-secure private-key encryption scheme, and ΠM\Pi_{M}ΠM​ is a strongly secure MAC, then the encrypt-then-authenticate approach is an authenticated encryption scheme. Note that the kEk_EkE​ and kMk_MkM​ must be independent to ensure CCA-secure, and this is a basic principle of cryptography: different instances of cryptographic primitives should always use independent keys.

Secure communication sessions

The authenticated encryption scheme does not suffice the following potential attacks:

  • Re-ordering attack: An attacker can swap the order of the messages.
  • Replay attack: An attacker can replay a valid ciphertext ccc sent previously by one of the parties.
  • Reflection attack: An attacker can take a ciphertext ccc sent from A to B and send it back to A.

To prevent the above attacks, a counter is used to prevent the first two and a directionality bit is used to prevent the third.

References

  1. Introduction to Modern Cryptography, Second Edition.
  2. Understanding Cryptography: A Textbook for Students and Practitioners (Chinese Version).

计算机组成原理：基于硬件原理的程序优化

发表于 2020-10-20 阅读次数：
本文字数： 2.9k 阅读时长 ≈ 3 分钟

  1. 对于一些简单的函数，用内联函数替换。即：将代码中调用函数的步骤用函数体填充。这样就减少了调用函数的开销。

  2. 消除循环的低效率。循环中可能存在需要执行多次，但是每次的计算结果都不变的表达式。此时可以把这一表达式移动到循环体之外。例如循环体的结束条件中，有时是以一个字符串的大小作为判据的。如果字符串的大小不变，那么不必每次调用strlen()函数，只需要在开始的时候调用一次即可。

  3. 消除不必要的内存引用。例如求一个数组A所有元素的累加和，并将结果写入到一个储存在内存的变量中（如调用函数时，通过指针*dest来读取一个存储在内存中的变量）。如果将表达式写为*dest=*dest+A[i]，那么对于每一个i值，表达式的每一步都要读取一次内存并写入一次内存。此时可以用一个临时变量acc来保存结果，直接将最后结果写入到*dest中，由于临时变量acc被储存在寄存器中，此时就避免了内存的频繁读写。

  4. 尽量用乘法代替除法，尽量用移位与加法运算代替乘除法。因为乘除法的在CPU计算时的延迟要大于加法，而除法的延迟又大于乘法且不是完全流水线化的。

  5. 循环展开。增加每一次迭代时的操作数，从而减小循环的迭代次数。在使用优化等级3及以上（即编译时加上-O3），编译器会自动进行循环展开。

  6. 提高并行性。由于CPU可以在每个时钟周期内执行多个操作（超标量），同时指令执行的顺序不一定与它们在机器级程序中的顺序一致，而且CPU的功能单元是流水线化的，因此可以使用一些办法来提高程序的并行性：

    1. 使用多个累积变量。 对于可结合和可交换的合并运算（如整数的累加累积，浮点数在相差不大情况下的累加和累积），可以将运算拆分成若干部分，并在最后合并结果。例如将一个n个数的累加拆分成2组n/2个数的累加，并在最后合并。对于延迟为L，容量为C的操作而言，循环展开因子至少为C*L时可以达到吞吐量界限。但是也并不意味着展开因子越多越好，由于寄存器的数量有限，如果临时变量过多，则会被保存到栈上去。

      例：同时使用循环展开与累积变量

    2. 重新结合变换。表达式acc=(acc*data[i])*data[i+1]与acc=acc*(data[i]*data[i+1])的运算所需时间是不同的。对于前者而言，需要等待括号内的值执行完之后才能执行下一步；而对于后者而言，由于CPU的流水线特性，计算括号内部分的时候，可以和acc的乘法运算同时进行。这样，就减少了计算数据流中关键路径上面操作的数量。

      又例：对于计算多项式的值，虽然第一段代码所需的乘法次数多于第二个，但是由于第一段代码中的两个乘法可以同时执行，因此反而第一段代码的速度更快

  7. 将条件语句修改为功能式的风格。由于处理器具有投机执行的特性，因此对于一些结果不可预知的条件语句(如循环语句属于可以预知的)，这样修改可以提高函数的效率。例如一个将数组a和b中较小的元素保存在a中，较大的元素保存在b中的函数（只写主体部分）：

    这一语句可修改为：

  8. 选择合适的算法与数据结构，充分使用硬件性能。

  9. 编写高速缓存友好的代码，即编写时间与空间局部性较好的代码。尽量增加对局部变量的反复引用；由于数据是以连续的块存储，因此在引用的时候尽量减小步长，例如引用数组的时候尽量由内到外引用，引用一个结构体的时候按照结构体中变量存储的顺序引用。

    例1：优化矩阵乘法

    例2：转置矩阵的时候，对矩阵分块进行操作

计算机网络：OSI七层模型

发表于 2020-10-20 阅读次数：
本文字数： 1.3k 阅读时长 ≈ 1 分钟

OSI七层模型

OSI（Open System Interconnect），即开放式系统互联。 一般都叫OSI参考模型，是ISO（国际标准化组织）组织在1985年研究的网络互连模型。ISO为了更好的使网络应用更为普及，推出了OSI参考模型。其含义就是推荐所有公司使用这个规范来控制网络。这样所有公司都有相同的规范。

OSI模型把网络从逻辑上分为七层，每一层都有相应的物理设备。它是一种框架式的设计方法，最主要的功能就是帮助不同类型的主机实现数据传输； 最大优点就是将服务、接口和协议三个概念明确的区分起来。但是这一模型复杂且不实用；在实际中，经常使用的是TCP/IP五层（或四层，将物理层与数据链路层看作同一层）模型。

OSI七层模型的示意图

为了使数据分组从源传送到目的地，源端OSI模型的每一层都必须与目的端的对等层进行通信，这种通信方式称为对等层通信。在每一层通信过程中，使用本层自己协议进行通信。

TCP/IP五层模型

在TCP/IP五层模型中，每一层都呼叫它的下一层提供的接口来完成自己的需求。（如果是四层模型数据链路层和物理层在一层） 在每一层实现的协议都不同，即每一层的服务不同。同时，每一层为了实现不同的服务，也工作着不同的设备。

  1. 物理层：负责光电信号传递方式。集线器工作在物理层。
  2. 数据链路层：负责设备之间的数据帧的传输和识别，例如网卡设备的驱动，帧同步，冲突检测，数据差错校验等工作。 交换机工作在数据链路层。
  3. 网络层：负责地址管理和路由选择。路由器工作在网络层。
  4. 传输层：负责两台主机之间的数据传输。
  5. 应用层：负责应用程序之间的沟通。网络编程主要针对的就是应用层。

应用层的封装在应用程序中完成；传输层和网络层的封装在操作系统完成；数据链路层和物理层的封装在设备驱动程序与网络接口中完成。

TCP/IP五层模型与OSI七层模型的对应关系如下：

数据传送

在信息的传递过程中，为了便于数据传输，从应用层向下的每一层都会为数据加一个报头，将其封装成包。在到达设备或是终端的时候，再层层拆包。其大致过程如下图所示

转载：信息安全与密码学博士应该掌握的52个知识点

发表于 2020-10-20 阅读次数：
本文字数： 5.4k 阅读时长 ≈ 5 分钟

Bristol大学的密码安全工作组为密码学和信息安全相关的博士准备了52个基本知识点，详情见http://www.cs.bris.ac.uk/Research/CryptographySecurity/knowledge.html。

密码学是一个高度跨学科的领域，包含纯数学、计算机科学以及电子工程等多方面的知识。考虑读研读博的学生专业知识背景不一，Bristol大学对这方面的知识点进行了一个全面的总结和覆盖。52个知识点，Bristol大学推荐所有博一学生花一年的时间应该基本掌握，也就是差不多一个星期掌握一个知识点。掌握这些知识点后，对之后的课堂学习、项目执行、论文研读、科研协作、参加国际会议、与密码学者沟通会大有益处；要不然，可能一直处于懵懵懂懂的状态，荒废学业。

目前Bristol大学的密码工作组也开了一个博客“http://bristolcrypto.blogspot.com/”（注意，Blogspot被墙了，需要使用代理或者翻墙工具访问，推荐Chrome浏览器+红杏插件）来分别分析这些知识点，截止写这篇博文前，该博客刚更新到第21个，相信每周都会增加。为了恶补，我的基本想法也是每周理解一篇然后总结博文吧。

下面列出这52个需要掌握的知识点：

Computer Engineering ([E]) 计算机工程方面

Number 1：What is the difference between the following?

  • A general-purpose processor.

  • A general-purpose processor with instruction-set extensions.

  • A special-purpose processor (or co-processor).

  • An FPGA.

Number 2：What is the difference between a multi-core processor and a vector processor?

Number 3：Estimate the relative computational and storage capabilities of…

  • a smart-card

  • a micro-controller (i.e. a sensor node)

  • an embedded or mobile computer (e.g., a mobile phone or PDA)

  • a laptop- or desktop-class computer.

Theoretical Computer Science ([F]) 理论计算机科学方面

Number 4：What is meant by the complexity class P?

Number 5：What is meant by the complexity class NP?

Number 6：How can we interpret NP as the set of theorems whose proofs can be checked in polynomial time?

Number 7：How does randomness help in computation, and what is the class BPP?

Number 8：How does interaction help in computation, and what is the class IP?

Number 9：What are Shannon’s definitions of entropy and information?

Mathematical Background ([A,B]) 数学背景

Number 10：What is the difference between the RSA and the Strong-RSA problem?

Number 11：What are the DLP, CDH and DDH problems?

Number 12：What is the elliptic curve group law?

Number 13：Outline the use and advantages of projective point representation.

Number 14：What is a cryptographic pairing?

Basic (Practical or Deployed) Cryptographic Schemes and Protocols ([A]) 基本密码机制与协议

Number 15：Describe the key generation, encryption and decryption algorithms for RSA-OAEP and ECIES.

Number 16： Describe the key generation, signature and verification algorithms for DSA, Schnorr and RSA-FDH.

Number 17：Describe and compare the round structure of DES and AES.
